text: [Music]
hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with warm goat cheese and peach
Tartine that's right and all Tartine is
is a fancy french word for an open-faced
sandwich really the same thing but if
you call Tartine you do get to charge a
couple more dollars and by the way
August is national goat cheese month and
one of my many missions I'm miss ER is
to somehow get Americans to eat more
goat cheese and besides that peaches are
just unbelievably awesome right now so
we're going to pair those together to
make an incredibly delicious and quick
summer lunch so step one we're going to
need some nice thick sliced bread I'm
using a loaf of French bread this is
sourdough which is always a nice choice
and when I say thickly cut I mean it
they should be between three quarters
and an inch thick what's that seven
eighths I've never been that good be
fractions I usually screw those up like
five thirds of the time it's terrible
all right so we're gonna take some
thickly cut bread and we're going to
toast it by the way this is much much
better if it's day-old or even worse all
right this works better with stale bread
I tried using fresh and it didn't work
as well but you'll read about that in
the blog post but anyway once that slice
we're going to throw in the toaster to
give it a head start on one quick pro
tip let the toast cool for a second
before you try to pull it out because
that was fairly painful but anyway we're
gonna transfer that onto a sheet pan
we're gonna douse it liberally with
olive oil yes do both sides please and
once that set up we are on to our goat
cheese spread so I have about four
ounces of fresh goat cheese also known
as Chev which I believe is the word for
goat and that seems like it would be
confusing in France but anyway not my
problem
so some fresh goat cheese I've left that
out at room temperature for about a
half-hour so it's easier to work with
and then to the cheese we're going to
add some freshly picked I'm by the way
this is why you have to have a time
plant in your windowsill or garden you
could find yourself with peaches cheese
and bread but you're probably not going
to walk to the store to buy a bunch of
time to get like two teaspoons but if
you have in the back yard you just pick
a little and it's so easy and by the way
as I'm picking this I'm kind of
squeezing those little leaves together
to release those oils smells incredible
I mean you make this you're gonna have
the best smelling fingertips in the
neighborhood and just assume that don't
go trying to prove it and then after the
time we're gonna add a whole bunch of
freshly ground black pepper and if
you're thinking didn't he do some
individual peach cobbler a few years
back they featured peaches with black
pepper and some herbs you are correct
and it was incredibly delicious and yes
that was one of the inspirations for
this lunch and that is pretty much it we
don't really need any salt there's
enough salt in the cheese if you want to
put a shake of cayenne in there who am I
to tell you not to so if you want to
warm it up a little bit go ahead
you are the Dean of your Tartine right
at that point we're going to take a
spatula and mix that up until it's all
incorporated and we want it nice and
soft and spreadable and then go ahead
and divide it between your two toasts
and as you're doing this step you only
have two things to worry about number
one that you get the same amount on each
and number two that you spread it all
the way to the absolute edge of the
toast because we're going to finish this
under the broiler if there's too much
exposed bread it will burn and it just
won't be as good okay so spread it all
the way to the edge just like you see me
doing here and then once you've done
that you're going to top it with three
beautifully thick slices of the sweetest
rye pused summer peach you can find that
is just a sight to behold and it's going
to take all your willpower to just not
eat it right now which by the way would
not be a bad idea totally delicious but
try to hold off because it's just so
much better warm and of course if you
don't have access to peaches and you
can't find or don't like goat cheese
feel free to substitute with order a
pizza okay final step before these go
under the broiler we're going to give
the tops a little drizzle with olive oil
and then just a little sprinkling of
salt it's going to bring out the
sweetness in those peaches and that is
ready for the oven
and by oven I mean broiler so I'm going
to brown that about 6 inches under the
broiler which is set to high heat and
it's going to take a couple minutes but
you'll know when you're done the top and
edges will be kind of browned and the
cheese will be heated all the way
through and that warm goat cheese and
peach Tartine is done look at that just
an amazing combination of flavors and of
course textures you get that crispy edge
bread that mild creamy but somewhat
tangy cheese which is balanced
beautifully by those sweet juicy peaches
just fantastic and my only criticism is
I touched on earlier the bread I used
was too fresh so it was not as crunchy
as I wanted but we can fix that and
you'll read about that in the blog post
so anyway if you love goat cheese and
we're looking for another delicious way
to enjoy it this is it or maybe you've
never had goat cheese before and this
inspires you to try it which I really
really really hope you
you since goat cheese really is an
incredible product it's like cream
cheese with benefits so I really do hope
you give this a try head over to food
wishes calm for all the ingredient
amounts and more info as usual and as
always enjoy
